question: Should voting be compulsory in the UK?

content.source_1: International IDEA Voter Turnout Database (Voter Turnout, global): Comparative data show countries with compulsory voting (e.g., Australia, Belgium) consistently record turnout around 85–95% of registered voters, while recent UK general elections have been markedly lower (about 60–67%), indicating compulsion is associated with substantially higher participation.
content.source_2: Arend Lijphart, “Unequal Participation: Democracy’s Unresolved Dilemma,” American Political Science Review (1997): Lijphart argues compulsory voting is the most effective reform for reducing socioeconomic turnout gaps, enhancing political equality by bringing lower-income and less-educated citizens into the electorate.
content.source_3: Australian Parliamentary Library, Quick Guide on informal and “donkey” voting (e.g., Damon Muller, Informal voting in recent federal elections): Documents that Australia’s compulsory system sees non-trivial levels of informal ballots (about 5–6% in the 2019 federal election) and ballot-order “donkey voting,” raising concerns about the quality and sincerity of some compelled votes.
content.source_4: Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (Cth), s.245 (Australia): Establishes legal enforcement of compulsory voting and a penalty (typically A$20 for failing to vote without valid reason), illustrating the coercive mechanism and administrative burden required to pursue and fine non-voters.
content.source_5: UK House of Commons Political and Constitutional Reform Committee, “Voter engagement in the UK” (2014–15, HC 232): Considered compulsory voting but did not recommend it, citing civil liberties concerns and advocating alternative measures (e.g., improved registration, civic education, and electoral reforms) to boost engagement without coercion.
content.source_6: Venice Commission (Council of Europe), Code of Good Practice in Electoral Matters (2002, rev.): States that compulsory voting is not inherently contrary to free-election principles if sanctions are proportionate and non-excessive, indicating the policy would be legally compatible with European democratic standards if carefully designed.
